In a typical SSO solution, what is a "Service Provider"?
choices: A system or entity which provides business service(s) to users or other entities.
A person who provides various business services.

In SSO, typically a "service provider" is the entity which receives the SSO token --> then queries the "identity provider" to validate the token and establish the identity of the user being logged in before providing the requested business service(s).

question: In a typical SSO solution, what is an "Identity Provider"?
choices: A system or entity which can verify and prove identity of a user to other systems/entities involved in the SSO mechanism. Typically this is also the entity which generates and verifies the SSO token.
A system or entity which encrypts and provides password of a user to other systems/entities involved in the SSO mechanism so that they can re-authenticate the user.

choices: Information about the Identity. generally presented as key-value pairs

In public-key cryptography, owners keep their private-keys private and never exchange them. But, owners can share public keys anywhere they like. How can you be sure that the public key that one entity is using to communicate with the other entity is, in fact, that entity's public key? What if the public key, in fact, belongs to a malicious third party performing a man-in-the-middle attack? What is countermeasure to avoid this scenario?

choices: Typically, it is the alphanumeric user id used to login to an application/system. It uniquely identifies the user.
It is the user's biometric identifier such as thumb impression. It uniquely identifies the user.
It is the electronic identifier assigned to the user to uniquely identify him/her. E.g. The RFID enabled ID card.

Since a SSO "token" is a "master key" to get access to multiple systems/applications with a "single" login, it is extremely important to protect this master key from theft, spoofing or forgery. What are typical ways to protect the SSO token from various threats?
choices: Invalidate the SSO token on server side for subsequent use after the user logs off from any of the SSO enabled applications/systems i.e. after Single Sign-Off.
If the SSO token is being exchanged using a HTTP cookie, set the "HttpOnly" attribute of the cookie to prevent cookie access via client side javascript.
Define a server-side "timeout" for SSO token. The token should be invalid for use after the timeout period.
Digitally sign the SSO token to protect against man-in-the-middle manipulations and also encrypt the token with a time variant encryption key/algorithm. Exchange the token over SSL.

Implement a "source IP check" i.e. The source IP of the end client device which was used to provide the user credentials to generate the SSO token for the first time, should match the source IP of the end client device for all subsequent requests containing the same SSO token.

question: The use of proper security techniques can:
Though Single Sign-On (SSO) improves "user experience", it may come with some security risks of its own. What are the security risks associated with SSO?
choices: The SSO token is now a kind of a "master key" to gain access to multiple applications/systems. If an adversary can steal, spoof or forge this master key, he/she can gain such access without the need to know the actual userid or password.

Especially in the case when a user uses the SSO mechanism from a smart mobile device like iPhone, iPad, the risk of losing the SSO token (or that "master-key") is hightened because the device itself can be stolen/lost after the user has logged in with credentials.
SSO is well secure by default.

question: What from the following verifies correctness, completeness and robustness of the design?

What is "federated SSO"?
choices: SSO across federal states of a nation.
A mechanism that can provide a SSO token which can be trusted for identity assertion by multiple entities across multiple "identity management systems" such as multiple organizations.

question: What is "OAuth"?
choices: OAuth (Open Authorization) is an open standard that allows users to securely share their credentials, typically username and password with other websites or entities.

"OAuth (Open Authorization) is an open standard that allows users to share their personal resources stored on one site with another site without having to hand out their credentials, typically username and password."

question: What is a "principal" in the context of "authentication"?
choices: It is an authentication mechanism through witch user will enter principal value during authentication.
An entity which can be authenticated by a system, typically using the identifier associated with that entity.

A person, computer, printer or any device or a group of these can be termed as a "principal". E.g. A person can be given a "user id" as an identifier which can then be used by a system to authenticate him/her.

question: What is a "Single Sign-On (SSO) token"?
choices: A "SSO token" is a token that represents or asserts the logged in user's "identity" & can be used to gain access to multiple applications/systems participating in the SSO mechanism without need to re-login with user's actual identifier/identity like user id and password.
It is the token one has to use to do any transaction at a bank counter.
A SSO token is nothing but concatenation of user id and password.

question: What is a salted hash?
choices: A hash that has been tested against known attacks
Combining a username with a hash of username and hashing it
A hash encrypted with a symmetric key

question: What is Microsoft STRIDE model?
What is not a best practice for password policy?
choices: Restriction on password reuse and history

question: What is not a good practice for user administration?
choices: Isolating a system after a compromise
Granting privileges on a per host basis
Using telnet and FTP for remote access

question: What is SAML?
choices: An open standard to securely exchange authentication/identity and authorization information between an identity provider and a service provider. A SAML token is based on XML.
It is a secure, SSO specification from Microsoft.

question: What is Single Sign-Off?
choices: A mechanism of signing off from any application.
A mechanism that enables turning off digital signatures.

A mechanism that enables logging off from / terminates access to multiple "Single Sign-On" enabled applications/systems by logging off from just one of the "Single Sign-On" enabled application/system.

question: What is Single Sign-On (SSO)?
choices: A mechanism of digitally "signing" the information exchanged between applications/systems.

A mechanism that enables a user to sign-in/login/authenticate to an application/system with his credentials only once and then seamlessly access other applications/systems available in the same domain of trust (e.g. intranet portal of an organization) without the need to re-login with the credentials again.
A mechanism which enables using single physical "signature" to do all banking transactions!

Hashing functions are two way functions

choices: "User experience" is improved as the user does not have to enter credentials for every new application access.
Reduces the number of "passwords" to remember, secure and manage. With SSO, a single login with user id and password enables "secure" access to multiple applications.
Simplifies "identity & access management". This is because single/same identity can now be centrally managed and securely propagated to all target applications or service providers.

question: Why is one time password safe?
choices: It is different for every access

question: You are one of those who is taking care of application security in your application. One of your team mates asks you, "Why we need such sophisticated SSO "solutions" when the simplest SSO solution is to simply capture logged in user's login credentials (id, password) and circulate to all concerned service providers or apps? Those service providers or apps can then re-authenticate the user using the provided credentials. Simple!". As an application security care-taker, which one of the following should be your response to your team mate?
choices: Disagree. "One of the goals of the SSO concept was to eliminate the need to key-in (multiple) passwords multiple times and thus eliminate circulation of password(s) to gain access to multiple applications/systems. So, though your SSO solution sounds simple, it's not at all secure and it's against the principles of SSO."
Agree to his proposal. Along with it we need to implement secure token based authentication.

question: Your application sets a cookie with Secure attribute. What does this mean?
choices: Client will send the cookie only over an HTTPS connection
Client will send cookie over HTTP connection
